unnormalised: Okay, so online learning, right? It's become HUGE in India, especially after 2020. Everyone's suddenly a tech guru, or at least pretending to be! My little cousin, Rohan, who's, like, in Class 7 at Ryan International, practically lives on Byju's.
normalised: Okay, so online learning, right? It's become huge in India, especially after two thousand and twenty. Everyone's suddenly a tech guru, or at least pretending to be! My little cousin, Rohan, who's, like, in Class seven at Ryan International, practically lives on B-Y-J-U's.

unnormalised: Before, you had to physically be in Delhi or Mumbai to get the best coaching for IIT-JEE or NEET. Now, even folks in smaller towns like Guwahati can access top-notch teachers via Vedantu or Unacademy. It's a total game-changer! And the prices? Used to be like Rs. 50,000+ for a year of coaching. Now, you can often find courses for ₹20,000 or even less if you catch a sale.

unnormalised: My aunt, Priya aunty, actually enrolled in an online coding bootcamp from Masai School. She’s 45, and she’s learning Python! Seriously impressive. Says it's all live classes and stuff, no pre-recorded lectures that you just doze off during. The commitment's 9 AM to 9 PM, Mon-Sat. Talk about intense!

unnormalised: The EdTech companies are also going crazy with marketing. Every other ad on YouTube is for some online course or another. Plus, all these 'success stories' – "Ramesh scored 99% in his Class 10 boards thanks to XYZ coaching!" You have to wonder how much is real and how much is, well, marketing hype.

unnormalised: One thing that's definitely a problem is screen time. Kids are already glued to their phones all day, now they're spending even MORE time staring at screens for school! Dr. Sharma, my family doc, says he’s seeing more kids complaining of headaches and eye strain. Needs some serious regulation, I think. 10-year-olds shouldn't be burning the midnight oil on devices every single night, right?

unnormalised: But hey, the convenience is undeniable. No more crazy commutes in the Delhi heat to get to tuition classes. Learn from the comfort of your own home, in your pyjamas, with a cup of chai. Can’t beat that, can you? Plus, my neighbour’s daughter cleared the UPSC Civil Services exam in 2023 studying almost entirely online.

unnormalised: Overall, online learning in India is a mixed bag. It's opened up opportunities for so many, but it's also created new challenges. We need to figure out how to make it sustainable and healthy for our kids. Maybe some mandatory screen breaks, or limits on the amount of time kids can spend on devices per day? Just a thought!
